A **gnoll cleric**, h, is a type of [monster](/wiki/Monster "Monster") that appears in [EvilHack](/wiki/EvilHack "EvilHack"). It is a [gnoll](/wiki/Gnoll_\(monster_attribute\) "Gnoll (monster attribute)") that has [infravision](/wiki/Infravision "Infravision") and can be seen via infravision, and is capable of casting [monster spells](/wiki/Monster_spell "Monster spell").

A gnoll cleric has a bite attack and will attempt to cast one clerical monster spell during each of their turns, and possesses [poison resistance](/wiki/Poison_resistance "Poison resistance").

Eating a gnoll cleric [corpse](/wiki/Corpse "Corpse") or [tin](/wiki/Tin "Tin") can confer [telepathy](/wiki/Telepathy "Telepathy"), as with the corpses of other spellcasting monsters.

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)
- [2 Strategy](#Strategy)
- [3 Origin](#Origin)
- [4 Encyclopedia entry](#Encyclopedia_entry)

## Generation

Randomly generated gnoll clerics are always created hostile.

A gnoll cleric has a 3⁄4 chance of [being generated with](/wiki/Monster_starting_inventory "Monster starting inventory") [armor](/wiki/Plain_armor "Plain armor"), and an independent 1⁄5 chance of a [cloak](/wiki/Plain_cloak "Plain cloak").

## Strategy

Gnoll clerics can be unexpectedly deadly encounters in the mid-game: their spell list will always include the [paralyze](/wiki/Paralyze_\(monster_spell\) "Paralyze (monster spell)"), [vulnerability](/wiki/Vulnerability "Vulnerability") and [summon insects](/wiki/Summon_insects "Summon insects") monster spells, enabling them to make short work of characters that do not have a way to keep them out of melee range or handle swarms of [insects](/wiki/Insect "Insect") such as [soldier ants](/wiki/Soldier_ant "Soldier ant"), [fire ants](/wiki/Fire_ant "Fire ant") and even [illness](/wiki/Illness "Illness")-spreading [locusts](/wiki/Locust "Locust").

## Origin

[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[Gnole](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gnole "wikipedia:Gnole")***

The gnoll is a creature that appears in various types of fantasy media, and is generally portrayed as a human-hyena hybrid or a form of humanoid hyena. The term originates from 1912 short story collection *[The Book of Wonder](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Book_of_Wonder "wikipedia:The Book of Wonder")* by [Lord Dunsany](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lord_Dunsany "wikipedia:Lord Dunsany"), with one short story titled "How Nuth Would Have Practised His Art upon the Gnoles".

The gnoll of *[Dungeons & Dragons](/wiki/Dungeons_%26_Dragons "Dungeons & Dragons")* is introduced in [the first boxed set](https://archive.org/details/monsters_and_treasures/page/7/mode/2up) of the game, and gnolls are described in *Book 2: Monsters and Treasure* as a "cross between [Gnomes](/wiki/Gnome "Gnome") and [Trolls](/wiki/Troll "Troll") (...perhaps, Lord Sunsany did not really make it all that clear)". These early gnolls were stated to be similar to hobgoblins with +2 morale, while a gnoll king and his bodyguard fought similar to trolls without regenerative power. The 1st Monster Manual for *Advanced Dungeons & Dragons* and all subsequent material describe gnolls as aggressive desert-dwelling nomads that resemble humanoid hyenas, and actively raid and plunder other settlements; it also introduces [Yeenoghu](/wiki/Yeenoghu "Yeenoghu"), the demon god of gnolls who many of them serve and worship. This portrayal of gnolls is the basis for their appearance in EvilHack.

In spite of their devotion to Yeenoghu, few gnolls that worship him (or any other god in much rarer cases) have any interest in ritual, making actual gnoll shamans and clerics very uncommon and few in number - gnolls that worship Yeenoghu see their brutality as a sign of their devotion, painting the eye of Yeenoghu onto their weapons and armor and howling his name as a war cry in battle.

## Encyclopedia entry

We are born and we die.  
No one cares, no one remembers,  
and it doesn't matter.  
This is why we laugh.  
\[ The Gnoll Credo, by J. Stanton ]

Gnoll cleric

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search
h gnoll cleric (No tile)
Difficulty 10
Attacks Bite 1d4, Spell-casting 0d0 clerical
h gnoll cleric (No tile)
Difficulty 10
Attacks

Bite 1d4, Spell-casting 0d0 clerical

Base level 8
Base experience 83
Speed 9
Base AC 6
Base MR 30
Alignment -10 (chaotic)
Frequency (by normal means) 2 (Quite rare)
Genocidable Yes
Weight 1200
Nutritional value 300
Size Medium
Resistances poison
Resistances conveyed None

A gnoll cleric:

  • has a head, a couple of arms, and a torso.
  • is omnivorous.
  • is normally generated hostile.
  • is strong.
  • likes gold.
  • can pick up weapons and food.
  • has infravision.
  • can be seen through infravision.
Reference EvilHack - monst.c, line 610

A gnoll cleric, h, is a type of monster that appears in EvilHack. It is a gnoll that has infravision and can be seen via infravision, and is capable of casting monster spells.

A gnoll cleric has a bite attack and will attempt to cast one clerical monster spell during each of their turns, and possesses poison resistance.

Eating a gnoll cleric corpse or tin can confer telepathy, as with the corpses of other spellcasting monsters.

Contents

  • 1 Generation
  • 2 Strategy
  • 3 Origin
  • 4 Encyclopedia entry

Generation

Randomly generated gnoll clerics are always created hostile.

A gnoll cleric has a 3⁄4 chance of being generated with armor, and an independent 1⁄5 chance of a cloak.

Strategy

Gnoll clerics can be unexpectedly deadly encounters in the mid-game: their spell list will always include the paralyze, vulnerability and summon insects monster spells, enabling them to make short work of characters that do not have a way to keep them out of melee range or handle swarms of insects such as soldier ants, fire ants and even illness-spreading locusts.

Origin

Wikipedia has an article about:
Gnole

The gnoll is a creature that appears in various types of fantasy media, and is generally portrayed as a human-hyena hybrid or a form of humanoid hyena. The term originates from 1912 short story collection The Book of Wonder by Lord Dunsany, with one short story titled "How Nuth Would Have Practised His Art upon the Gnoles".

The gnoll of Dungeons & Dragons is introduced in the first boxed set of the game, and gnolls are described in Book 2: Monsters and Treasure as a "cross between Gnomes and Trolls (...perhaps, Lord Sunsany did not really make it all that clear)". These early gnolls were stated to be similar to hobgoblins with +2 morale, while a gnoll king and his bodyguard fought similar to trolls without regenerative power. The 1st Monster Manual for Advanced Dungeons & Dragons and all subsequent material describe gnolls as aggressive desert-dwelling nomads that resemble humanoid hyenas, and actively raid and plunder other settlements; it also introduces Yeenoghu, the demon god of gnolls who many of them serve and worship. This portrayal of gnolls is the basis for their appearance in EvilHack.

In spite of their devotion to Yeenoghu, few gnolls that worship him (or any other god in much rarer cases) have any interest in ritual, making actual gnoll shamans and clerics very uncommon and few in number - gnolls that worship Yeenoghu see their brutality as a sign of their devotion, painting the eye of Yeenoghu onto their weapons and armor and howling his name as a war cry in battle.

Encyclopedia entry

We are born and we die.
No one cares, no one remembers,
and it doesn't matter.
This is why we laugh.
[ The Gnoll Credo, by J. Stanton ]

A '''gnoll cleric''', {{brightblue|h}}, is a type of [[monster]] that appears in [[EvilHack]]. It is a [[Gnoll (monster attribute)|gnoll]] that has [[infravision]] and can be seen via infravision, and is capable of casting [[monster spell]]s.

A gnoll cleric has a bite attack and will attempt to cast one clerical monster spell during each of their turns, and possesses [[poison resistance]].

Eating a gnoll cleric [[corpse]] or [[tin]] can confer [[telepathy]], as with the corpses of other spellcasting monsters.

==Generation==
Randomly generated gnoll clerics are always created hostile.

A gnoll cleric has a {{frac|3|4}} chance of [[Monster starting inventory|being generated with]] [[Plain armor|armor]], and an independent {{frac|5}} chance of a [[Plain cloak|cloak]].

==Strategy==
Gnoll clerics can be unexpectedly deadly encounters in the mid-game: their spell list will always include the [[Paralyze (monster spell)|paralyze]], [[vulnerability]] and [[summon insects]] monster spells, enabling them to make short work of characters that do not have a way to keep them out of melee range or handle swarms of [[insect]]s such as [[soldier ant]]s, [[fire ant]]s and even [[illness]]-spreading [[locust]]s.

==Origin==
{{wikipedia|Gnole}}
The gnoll is a creature that appears in various types of fantasy media, and is generally portrayed as a human-hyena hybrid or a form of humanoid hyena. The term originates from 1912 short story collection ''[[wikipedia:The Book of Wonder|The Book of Wonder]]'' by [[wikipedia:Lord Dunsany|Lord Dunsany]], with one short story titled "How Nuth Would Have Practised His Art upon the Gnoles".

The gnoll of ''[[Dungeons & Dragons]]'' is introduced in [https://archive.org/details/monsters_and_treasures/page/7/mode/2up the first boxed set] of the game, and gnolls are described in ''Book 2: Monsters and Treasure'' as a "cross between [[Gnome]]s and [[Troll]]s (...perhaps, Lord Sunsany did not really make it all that clear)". These early gnolls were stated to be similar to hobgoblins with +2 morale, while a gnoll king and his bodyguard fought similar to trolls without regenerative power. The 1st Monster Manual for ''Advanced Dungeons & Dragons'' and all subsequent material describe gnolls as aggressive desert-dwelling nomads that resemble humanoid hyenas, and actively raid and plunder other settlements; it also introduces [[Yeenoghu]], the demon god of gnolls who many of them serve and worship. This portrayal of gnolls is the basis for their appearance in EvilHack.

In spite of their devotion to Yeenoghu, few gnolls that worship him (or any other god in much rarer cases) have any interest in ritual, making actual gnoll shamans and clerics very uncommon and few in number - gnolls that worship Yeenoghu see their brutality as a sign of their devotion, painting the eye of Yeenoghu onto their weapons and armor and howling his name as a war cry in battle.

==Encyclopedia entry==

	and it doesn't matter.
